Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?



Thus we can summarise the pattern for Exception testing:

try {
//tested code starts here.
...

fail( "should have thrown exception TestedException" )
} catch ( TestedException ) { return }
} catch ( Exception e ) { fail( "thrown wrong exception: "+e ); }


I have written an extension to TestCase, that gives the above behaviour.
Instead of the try/catch blocks, you call a single method at the beginning
of the test
shouldThrow( TestedException.class );
and the TestCase does the rest.

Anyone, let me know if it is of any interest.

(the reason I'm not sure its useful, is what Kent has written about the
simplicity of the framework: I'm not sure the complexity of adding an extra
method to TestCase justify the removal of the above 4-line patten)



"Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a
thrown exception ?



No. The fail() immediately following isPartnerAssigned() would fail the
test if the exception was not thrown. If any other exception is thrown, the
catch{} for those would fail the test. You could add another catch for
java.lang.Exception in case you think that might be thrown, but it doesn't
sound like the contract for your method.

-Jason
